content: Some validators are identical to test cases (1, 2, 11) would be better to use different values to properly validate solutions. Also validators 3-5 are just swapped inputs which doesn't help since the formula is symmetric.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I disapprove this contribution because the problem statement is unclear and does not explain the goal or the rules of the puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I love how many tests are there to make you think you got it, then swing you back into rethinking again, creating  a formula based on the quantity of tests need to be seen more often.

While players might get the logic eventually from reading the later tests, I think many players would get frustrated with trying to find the actual formula and drop the clash altogether. For example, having a different output (other than 100%) only from Test 6 onwards seems quite mean; not sure how much information players will be able to gain from those tests. Also, the max function would seem viable until Test 11, then min(a + b, 100) would be viable until Test 18. Test 20 is probably the first clearest example of which formula to apply.

May I suggest re-ordering the tests in such a way that the "clearer" examples (e.g. Test/Validator 20, 21, 24, 25) appear earlier? They need not be the first few examples, but they will help players get to the formula slightly faster, and make the clash slightly more playable.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The idea is good and the defi is fun
The logic is very difficult to find. Can’t you write a description and just use time and size of code mode?
There is a big hint in the title and the percent sign.

I'm surprised by your comment! I really thought having more tests was the opposite of mean, and I chose the order specifically to not be mean!

When we run the tests in the IDE, they run until the first test that doesn't pass, so it seems to me that if someone has a formula that works on most tests but not all, it's better if the tests that pass are first. Otherwise, if the formula fails early, they might think the formula is completely wrong, whereas in reality it still covers a relatively high percentage of tests.

(Remember, the ranking depends on how many tests you've covered correctly: 100% is better than 80%, which is better than 75%, which is better than 50%, etc)
Taking the max or the sum are both not far from the correct formula, and min(a+b, 100) is already really good and would bring a score of 68%

And if you already have min(a+b, 100), and you see that it works for the first 17 tests, then tests 18 and 19 are a really good hint for the correct formula (8% + 8% ~= 15% ! it's just missing one percent!)

To me, it's not obvious why there is a 1% difference in Tests 18 and 19. In fact, the 1% difference obscures the underlying multiplication; the actual difference from the expected sum is 0.64% and 0.99% respectively. Which is why I had to rely on Test 20 to figure that part out.

For me, I'm not fully satisfied with figuring out a partial formula or trying to score on as many tests as possible by returning the most common result (in this case, 100%). But I get what you mean by allowing players to score as best as possible and give them the feeling of making progress. I guess it just depends on play style.
I don't think a Fastest or Shortest mode would be interesting. It's the Reverse that makes it interesting.
The title won't be shown during a Reverse mode clash.
